Award.AwardTitle: The Adaptive Significance of an Evolutionary Constraint: from Protein to Organism
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will determine how the biophysical properties of amino acid mutations in a specific protein influence various levels of biological organization, ultimately affecting the capacity of individuals to live in various communities, and even influencing species interactions at a regional scale. The model system for this research is the interaction between toxic Pacific newts (Taricha) and their resistant predatory garter snakes (Thamnophis). Newts are defended by tetrodotoxin (TTX), one of the most lethal toxins ever discovered. This neurotoxin binds to the outer pore of voltage-gated sodium channels, the proteins responsible for propagating electrical impulses in muscles and nerves, thereby paralyzing muscle and nerve organs. Despite this, multiple garter snake species feast on newts, in large part due to specific changes to the sodium channel protein expressed in muscle. However, these adaptive variants likely bear a high cost; biophysical work on sodium channels suggests that amino acid mutations that reduce TTX binding to the protein are likely to reduce sodium channel function. If this tradeoff scales to the organism, then it may explain why TTX resistant garter snakes are geographically localized, and have not swept across the landscape. Further, this tradeoff may explain why resistance-conferring mutations in snakes represent only a small subset of mutations known to reduce TTX binding to the protein. Nevertheless, the cost of naturally occurring protein variants remains unexplored, as does any relationship between this biophysical tradeoff, tissue function, and organismal performance. Using a truly integrative approach, the investigators will: 1) quantify the apparent tradeoff in this molecular adaptation; 2) determine how resistance to prey toxin and biophysical tradeoffs scale up to the tissue; and 3) determine how tissue resistance and performance in different organs (muscle and nerve) combine to determine the adaptation of the snake. This research will provide a framework for understanding how a tradeoff at the molecular level can influence an individual's response to its environment, ultimately impacting adaptive evolution and species interactions across the landscape. The study provides a tractable model with a clear ecological context to help determine when and why adaptive evolution may be limited, as well as the possible downstream consequences of those constraints on adaptation.

The project will lead to training of two graduate students and several undergraduates in a highly integrative investigation where they will participate in molecular data generation, protein analysis, physiological assays, and whole organism performance trials, all in the context of predator-prey coevolution. The research themes of this project will be extended to an outdoor education program for families from Reno, Nevada. This project will sponsor 5 inner-city families to participate in a weekend-long outdoor program where they stay at a field station and explore the biodiversity and ecology of forest ecosystems that exist only 30 minutes from the urban setting in which they live. Applications will be made available to elementary and middle school children engaged in the UNR Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement program (MESA). MESA strives to engage low-income, first-generation students and will be an ideal conduit for identifying students that have interest in science but with financial needs that would otherwise preclude attendance of a program like Family Camp. The PI has chosen a family-based model because he has observed that exposing an individual child to this nature-based experience has a much higher and longer-lasting impact if their immediate family participates as well. This model provides a set of positive, shared family experiences that can be remembered and reinforced, creating a supportive environment as the child continues to develop and explore an interest in science. Such educational opportunities are particularly rare in an EPSCoR state like Nevada but will have significant impact on promoting biodiversity and organismally-based research and education in our community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Does evolution by the process of natural selection have limits?  Or given enough time and genetic inputs (mutations), can natural selection always fit organisms optimally to their environments?  The purpose of this NSF award was to understand whether and how evolution may be constrained.  The question is timely, because rapid anthropogenic changes (global warming, habitat fragmentation and degradation, pollution, invasive species, etc.) pose difficult and dynamic evolutionary challenges for much of the world’s biodiversity.  And the issue of evolutionary constraints has real implications for human health, well-being, and biotechnological advances.  Can we make antibiotics that microbes cannot overcome, or pesticides that insects cannot evolve resistance to, or algae that create ever more rich biofuels?  Most work on evolutionary constraints examines genetic mutations in microbes, focusing how mutations that are beneficial in one context limit or prevent adaptations in another context.  There has been almost no work on more complex organisms in natural settings.

We examined how naturally occurring mutations that benefit one aspect of an organism may impair another trait, and thus limit the evolutionary potential of those organisms.  The model system for this research is the interaction between toxic Pacific newts (Taricha) and their resistant predatory garter snakes (Thamnophis).  Newts are defended by tetrodotoxin (TTX), one of the most lethal toxins ever discovered (1000 times deadlier than cyanide).  This neurotoxin binds to the outer pore of voltage-gated sodium channels, essential proteins that all animals possess to allow electrical impulses in nerves and muscles.  By blocking these channels, TTX inhibits electrical activity in muscles and nerves, causing paralysis and death.  Despite this, multiple garter snake species can feast on newts.  Our previous work, and that of this award, details how specific amino acid mutations in the outer pore of the sodium channel expressed in muscle (Nav1.4) reduce the ability of TTX to bind to sodium channels, allowing these snakes to eat their deadly prey.  However, we show that these same mutations bear a high cost.  We conducted biophysical work on sodium channels and demonstrate that mutations that reduce TTX binding to the pore also severely reduce sodium channel function.  We show that mutant sodium channels are roughly half as effective and TTX-sensitive sodium channels.  Because this protein is expressed in muscle tissue, and essential for muscle function, we determined how this molecular tradeoff scales-up to the organ level.  We conducted muscle experiments and show that snakes with TTX-resistant mutations not only have hypofunctional sodium channels, but also suffer from compromised muscular performance.  The muscles of these TTX-resistant snakes were roughly half as quick and half as powerful as their TTX-sensitive counterparts.  Additionally, we found that muscle performance is further dampened at colder temperatures.  Lastly, we sought to determine how tradeoffs in muscle tissue impact whole-animal performance.  Interestingly, we found only modest evidence that the biophysical tradeoff found in sodium channels, which directly transmits to muscular deficits, scales-up to the whole-organism.  Snakes with TTX-resistant mutations suffer no obvious energetic costs at rest, and can sprint at roughly the same rates as other snakes (depending on the metric).  Over longer distances, some populations do seem slower, and perform fewer energetically costly avoidance behaviors.  Overall, we quantify a novel relationship between a biophysical tradeoff, tissue function, and organismal performance.  These data suggest that mutations promoted by natural selection for one trait can directly impact other traits.  Nevertheless, the cost of these mutations was not as dramatic at the whole-animal level, suggesting that in complex organisms, natural selection can modify other genes to rescue function.  Perhaps then, in some systems, natural selection can eventually circumvent the hurdles that previous adaptations have created, allowing populations to respond to the environmental challenges they face.

We have disseminated our work in 7 peer-reviewed publications and 2 natural history notes, with 2 more papers in review, and another 2 in preparation (we will produce several more in the coming months).  We gave 36 presentations at international, regional, and local conferences; 30 of these were given by our students who won 12 awards.  We provided training to 7 graduate students, 2 post-graduates, and lab or field opportunities to 17 undergraduates, including a capstone project for 5 engineering students and projects for 4 biology senior theses.  We also contributed over 500 biological specimens (with tissues) to museums and archived their gene sequences (GenBank).

Finally, we broadly participated in science education and engaged in public outreach.  We worked with an author of Biological Sciences to incorporate aspects of our research into this undergraduate textbook.  We also discussed our work during UNR Museum of Natural History events, and created an outreach module based on our system that graduate students provide to visiting K-12 groups.  Lastly, we created a new public display that includes live animals.  During the course of this award, we probably reached over 3000 K-12 students and parents.
